journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Stress concentration factor in the matrix reinforced with fiber having an interface layer

contrib-group.aff: School of Aerospace Engineering & Applied Mechanics, Tongji University, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Zheng-Ming Huang, School of Aerospace Engineering & Applied Mechanics, Tongji University, 1239 Siping Road, Shanghai 200092, China. Email: huangzm@mail.tongji.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Bridging Model is a versatile micromechanical theory, which can be used to simulate nonlinear behavior and ultimate strength of a laminated composite. The application of the Bridging Model requires input data of the in-situ mechanical properties of its constituents. A previous research has shown that the in-situ transverse strength of the matrix is equal to the pure matrix strength divided by a stress concentration factor along that direction. The stress concentration factor therein, however, was obtained based on a perfect bonding assumption between the fiber and the matrix. In this paper, a more general case is concerned. Namely, an interface layer is assumed to exist between the fiber and the matrix. Explicit expression for the stress concentration factor with an imperfect fiber and matrix interface bonding is obtained. The effect of the interface layer on the stress concentration factor is discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fiber-reinforced composites have been used more and more widely in various fields of engineering. Their ultimate strength is an important index for applications. A great many efforts have been made to develop reliable strength theories for composites in the past several decades. These theories can be classified into two categories, macromechanical and micromechanical. Compared with the fist category, a micromechanical strength theory has a unique advantage: it can directly calculate the strength of a composite without experiments on it, but only using its constituent properties together with necessary geometric parameters such as a fiber volume fraction. So the cost of predicting the composite strength is greatly reduced, and a from constituent bottom up to structure design can be achieved.

Bridging Model1,2 is a versatile micromechanics theory for constitutive description of a composite. The internal stresses in the constituent fiber and matrix materials under arbitrary load condition can be evaluated by the model. It has also been advanced to predict laminate strengths with sufficient accuracy.3 The use of the Bridging Model, however, needs to input in-situ mechanical properties of the constituents. Experimental results indicate that the transverse tensile strength of a unidirectional composite is generally smaller than the matrix pristine strength,4 showing that the in-situ strength of the matrix in the composite can be different from its original strength measured using monolithic material specimens. In the current literature, back retrieving on the experimental data of the composite has been applied to obtain the in-situ strengths of the matrix as well as other properties if necessary.1,2,5,6 Although all of the other constituent properties except for the matrix in-situ strengths in applying the Bridging Model can be taken to be those measured independently, the retrieval on the matrix in-situ strengths still requires experiments on the composite. This is a main drawback that remains to be addressed.

In Reference [7], Huang and Liu found that the in-situ transverse strength of the matrix is equal to the pure matrix strength divided by the stress concentration factor (SCF) along that direction. Using the thus obtained matrix strengths together with other independently provided constituent properties, the Bridging Model predictions for the World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE) problems correlated reasonably well with the available experimental data. In this way, the superiority of the Bridging Model has been improved greatly since no experiments on a composite itself will be necessary.

However, the composite considered in Reference [7] has been assumed to have a perfect bonding between the fiber and the matrix. This is not always the case in practice. This paper deals with a more general case. Namely, an interface layer is assumed to exist between the fiber and the matrix. There are several reasons for introducing an interface layer. Firstly, coating on fibers with a different, generally softer material is applied in order to reduce stress concentration or increase surface adhesion between the fiber and the matrix. The coating layer constitutes the interface layer.8,9 Secondly, an interface layer may also appear due to chemical reaction or diffusion during manufacturing process of a composite.10,11 In any case, the presence of an interface layer practically affects stress distributions in the fiber and the matrix and needs to be taken into account. For this purpose, a third-phase material is introduced to represent the interface layer, whereas the surfaces between the fiber and the interface layer and between the interface layer and the matrix are generally assumed to be perfectly bonded.12

Numerous studies have been carried out to investigate effects of an interface layer on stress distribution in a composite. For a very thin interface layer, Hashin13 assumed that the stresses and displacements changed linearly along thickness direction of the interface layer and obtained the exact solution for stress fields subjected to a transverse shear force. Taking a three-phase model subjected to a remote uniaxial tension in transverse direction, at least three research groups have obtained analytical expressions for the stress fields in all of the fiber, interface layer and matrix phases. Al-Ostaz and Jasiuk14 obtained a closed-form solution of suitable Airy’s stress functions for the considered problem. Sudak and Mioduchowski15 applied Muskhelishvili’s method to solve the problem and found explicit complex potential functions for the problem. Benveniste et al.16 got their solutions by employing displacement trial functions and a superposition method. In addition, Mogilevskaya and Crouch17 presented a Galerkin’s boundary integral method for solving the problem of an infinite, isotropic elastic plane containing a large number of randomly distributed circular elastic inclusions with uniform interface layers. Luo and Gao’s study18 reported an effective approach for a plane problem of a coated inclusion of arbitrary shape embedded in an isotropic matrix subjected to a uniform transverse load at infinity based on the complex variable method combined with expansions of Faber and Laurent series. Mikata and Taya19 studied a four-phase model, i.e. fiber-interphase-matrix-composite, and obtained closed-form solutions of it subjected to along fiber axial and uniform radial loads, respectively.

In this paper, we use a thin interface layer to investigate the effect of an imperfectly bonded surface on an in-situ strength of the matrix material, as ubiquity of such a layer is demonstrated with experiments.20,21 The stress fields in all of the three phases, which constitute geometry of a coated cylindrical fiber cylinder embedded in an infinite matrix, can be obtained based on Al-Ostaz and Jasiuk’s work14 through a series of derivations. Determination of an SCF is done following Reference [7], and the in-situ strength of the matrix along the corresponding load direction is defined as the matrix monolithic strength divided by the SCF. The aim of this work is to reveal the influence of varied interface layer conditions on the SCF and then on the in-situ transverse strength of the matrix.

sec.title: Summary of bridging model
sec.p: In the Bridging Model, the stress increments generated in the matrix and the fiber can be correlated by a bridging matrix through (6){dσim}=[Aij]{dσif}

Explicit expressions for the elements of an instantaneous bridging matrix can be found in, e.g., Reference [1]. If, in addition to the applied external stress increments {dσj}, there is a temperature variation dT = T1–T0, the internal stress increments in the fiber and the matrix are then modified to1 (10.1){dσif}=(Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1{dσj}+{bif}dT, (10.2){dσim}=[Aij](Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1{dσj}+{bim}dT, (10.3){bim}=([I]-[Aij](Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1)([Sijf]-[Sijm])-1 ({αjm}-{αjf}), (10.4){bif}=VmVf([I]-[Aij](Vf[I]+Vm[Aij])-1) ([Sijf]-[Sijm])-1({αjf}-{αjm}), where {αjf} and {αjm} are the thermal expansion coefficient vectors of the fiber and matrix, respectively. It is noted that all of the material parameters including the bridging matrix [Aij] should be provided at the temperature T0.
Thus, as long as a Vc is not negligible compared with Vf and Vm, the Bridging Model equations, (7)–(10), must be modified.

sec.title: Stress field in matrix
sec.p: The internal stresses in the fiber and matrix given by equations (7) and (8) or equations (10.1) and (10.2) are homogenized quantities, from which one cannot know any detail of local stress distribution. In order to define a SCF, the stress field, i.e., point-wise stress distribution, in the matrix must be determined as well.

Consider an infinite matrix having a circular fiber cylinder in its center. Between the matrix and fiber, there is an interface layer which has different properties from those of the other two materials. The matrix at its infinite boundary is subjected to a uniform load along z direction (Figure 2 with b→∞). All of the three component materials, i.e. the fiber, interface layer and the matrix, are assumed to be linearly elastic and isotropic. The bonds between the fiber and the interface layer and between the interface layer and the matrix are perfect. Namely, both displacements and stresses across these bonding surfaces are continuous. Based on the rigorous elasticity theory, the Airy stress functions in the fiber, interface layer and the matrix, which automatically satisfy the corresponding equilibrium equations, have been given by Al-Ostaz and Jasiuk14 as (14)Um=σ04(r2+r2cos2θ+Alogr+Bcos2θr2+Ccos2θ) (15)Uf=σ04(Dr2+Fr2cos2θ+Gr4cos2θ) (16)Uc=σ04(Hr2+Jlogr+Lcos2θr2+Mcos2θ +Nr2cos2θ+Qr4cos2θ) where the superscripts m, f and c refer to matrix, fiber and interface layer, respectively, A,B,C,D,F,G,H,J,L,M,N,Q are the integral constants to be determined by applying the suitable boundary conditions.

From equations (14), (15) and (16) and (A-1) given in Appendix, we obtain the stress components in the respective phases as (17.1)σrm=σ04r4[r2(A+2r2)-2(3B+2Cr2+r4)cos2θ] (17.2)σθm=σ04[2-Ar2+(2+6Br4)cos2θ] (17.3)σrθm=σ02r4(-3B-Cr2+r4)sin2θ (18.1)σrf=σ02(D-Fcos2θ) (18.2)σθf=σ02[D+(F+6Gr2)cos2θ] (18.3)σrθf=σ02(F+3Gr2)sin2θ (19.1)σrc=σ04r4[r2(J+2Hr2)-2(3L+2Mr2+Nr4)cos2θ] (19.2)σθc=σ04r4[-Jr2+2Hr4+2(3L+Nr4+6Qr6)cos2θ] (19.3)σrθc=σ02r4(-3L-Mr2+Nr4+3Qr6)sin2θ

The radial and tangential displacements are obtained from the stress–strain relations (A-2) and the strain-displacement relations (A-3) as (20.1)um=-σ0(1+μm){r2[A+2r2(-1+2μm)]-2{B-r2[r2+2C(-1+μm)]}cos2θ}4Emr3+f1(θ) (20.2)vm=σ0(1+μm){B+r2[r2+C(-1+2μm)]}sin2θ2Emr3-∫f1(θ)dθ+f1(r) (21.1)uf=-rσ0(1+μf)[D(-1+2μf)+(F+2Gr2μf)]cos2θ2Ef+f2(θ) (21.2)vf=-rσ0(1+μf)[-F+Gr2(-3+2μf)]sin2θ2Ef-∫f2(θ)dθ+f2(r) (22.1)uc=σ0(1+μc){-r2[J+2Hr2(-1+2μc)]+2[L-r2(-2M+Nr2+2Mμc+2Qr4μc)]cos2θ}4Ecr3+f3(θ) (22.2)vc=σ0(1+μc){L+r2{r2[N+Qr2(3-2μc)]+M(-1+2μc)}}sin2θ2Ecr3-∫f3(θ)dθ+f3(r) where Ej is elastic modulus and μj is Poisson's ratio with j = m, f, c.

The boundary conditions are at infinity:(σrm)r=∞=σ02(1-cos2θ), (σrθm)r=∞=σ0sin2θ2 atr=0:uf=0,vf=0;atr=a:σrc=σrf,σrθc =σrθf,uc=uf,vc=vf;and atr=a+t:σrc=σrm,σrθc=σrθm,uc=um,vc=vm where a is the fiber radius and t is the thickness of the interface layer.

Substituting the expressions of stress and displacement components into the boundary conditions results in (23.1)-3B+3L-2(a+t)2(C-M)+(a+t)4(-1+N)=0 (23.2)A-2(a+t)2(-1+H)-J=0 (23.3)6L+4a2M-2a4(F-N)=0 (23.4)2a4(D-H)-a2J=0 (23.5)3(B-L)+(a+t)2(C-M)+(a+t)4(-1+N)+3(a+t)6Q=0 (23.6)3L+a2M+a4(F-N)+3a6(G-Q)=0 (23.7)(1+μc){(a+t)2[J+2(a+t)2H(-1+2μc)]}Ec-(1+μm){(a+t)2[A+2(a+t)2(-1+2μm)]}Em=0 (1+μc){{-2L+2(a+t)2[-2M+(a+t)2N+2Mμc+2(a+t)4Qμc]}}Ec- (23.8)(1+μm){2[(a+t)4-B+2(a+t)2C(-1+μm)]}Em=0 (23.9)(1+μc){a2[J+2a2H(-1+2μc)]}a3Ec-2a(1+μf)[D(-1+2μf)]Ef=0 (23.10)(1+μc){[-2L+2a2(-2M+a2N+2Mμc+2a4Qμc)]}a3Ec-2a(1+μf)[(F+2a2Gμf)]Ef=0 (23.11) -(1+μc){L+(a+t)2[(a+t)2N+(a+t)4Q(3-2μc)+M(-1+2μc)]}Ec +(1+μm)[(a+t)4+B+(a+t)2C(-1+2μm)]Em=0 (23.12)(1+μc){L+a2[a2N+a4Q(3-2μc)+M(-1+2μc)]}Ec+a14(1+μf)[-F+a2G(-3+2μf)]Ef=0 Solving the above linear algebraic equations (23.1)–(23.12) simultaneously, the unknown constants A,B,C,D,F,G,H,J,K,L,M,N,Q can be determined.

sec.title: Stress concentration factor
sec.p: As mentioned in Reference [7], an SCF should be influenced by three kinds of conditions. First, it should be closely related to a loading direction. The present work corresponds to a transverse load on the composite. Second, an SCF should depend on the fiber, matrix and interface layer properties. Third, an SCF should be a function of the fiber volume fraction of the composite and the thickness of the interface layer.
Through a coordinate transformation, the stress component in the z direction of the matrix is given by (24)σzm=σrmsin2θ+σθmcos2θ+σrθmsin2θ

Following Reference [7], the SCF is defined as an averaged quantity based on the matrix stress components within the RVE. For this purpose, we isolate the fiber together with the interface layer using a co-axial matrix cylinder (Figure 2) with b=a/Vf.
We calculate an averaged stress of σzm along a line parallel to z axis (25)KθI=1(zb-za)∫zazbσzmσ0|y=yθdz where za=(a+t)sinθ, yθ=(a+t)cosθ,zb=b2-(yθ)2.
We then define the first portion of the SCF as KI=max{KθI,0∘≤θ≤90∘}

As will be shown subsequently, KI generally assumes its maximum value at θ = 90° when the fiber is stiffer than the matrix. In such a case, one can obtain (26)KI=1(b-a-t)∫a+tbσzmσ0|θ=90∘dz=1+(1+γ)[M1M2-(1+γ)2M3M4]Vf2(1+γ)2M3M5+M1M6 -2(1+γ)[-4(1+γ)2M62M7+M9M10+(1+γ)8M10M11+6(1+γ)4M62M12-4(1+γ)6M8M12]Vf-4(1+γ)2M7M16+(1+γ)8M18M11+6(1+γ)4M16M12-4(1+γ)6M17M12+M9M15 +(1+γ)[-4(1+γ)2M62M7+M9M10+(1+γ)8M10M11+2(1+γ)4M12M13-4(1+γ)6M12M14]Vf[1+(1+γ)Vf+(1+γ)2Vf]-8(1+γ)2M7M16+2(1+γ)8M18M11+12(1+γ)4M16M12-8(1+γ)6M17M12+M9M15 where γ=ta and M1–M18 are coefficients related to the properties of the fiber, matrix and the interface layer. The expressions of M1–M18 are given in the Appendix.

It is noted that KI is a dimensionless stress averaged along a straight line in the matrix domain of the RVE. On the other hand, the stress component (σzm)b computed through the Bridging Model is averaged on the whole matrix domain. Due to this reason, the second portion of the SCF is defined as (27.1)KII=(σzm)avg(σzm)b=1π[b2-(a+t)2]∫02π∫a+tbσzmrdrdθ(σzm)b
It is noted that (σzm)avg=σ0, (σzm)b=[βEf+(1-β)Em]σ0Ef(Vf+Vmβ)+Vm(1-β)Em, β is one of the bridging parameters. So we obtain (27.2)KII=(σzm)avg(σzm)b=Ef(Vf+Vmβ)+Vm(1-β)EmβEf+(1-β)Em
Therefore, the SCF of the matrix due to a transverse load on the composite is given by (28)K=KI×KII

It should be realized that when the fiber used becomes transversely isotropic, the Young’s modulus and Poisson’s ratio, Ef and μf, involved in equation (28) should be changed to the transverse counterparts, E22f and μ23f, of the fiber, respectively.

sec.title: Application
sec.p: An SCF as defined above will influence the analysis of a composite in two aspects. First, it will affect failure detection of a composite. Second, it will have an effect on plastic behavior of the matrix material.

sec.title: Failure detection
sec.p: For fiber failure, no difference occurs due to the introduction of an SCF in the matrix. A fiber tensile failure is detected using a generalized maximum normal stress failure criterion1 once the internal stresses in the fiber are computed through the Bridging Model, as per the following condition (29.1)σeq,tf≥σu,tf, (29.2)σeq,tf={σf1,whenσf3<0,[(σf1)q+(σf2)q]1q,whenσf3=0,
On the other hand, a fiber compressive failure is detected through (30)σf3≤-σu,cf.

In the above, σf1, σf2 and σf3 (with σf1≥σf2≥σf3) are the three principal stresses of the fiber due to combined thermal and mechanical loads, σu,tf and σu,cf are the fiber tensile and compressive strengths along its axial direction and q is a power-index (q = 3 in this paper).
For the matrix, because its in-situ strengths are different along different directions, we choose to use Tsai-Wu criterion to assess its failure.

Incorporated with the SCF, the expression of Tsai-Wu criterion for the matrix can be written as (31.1)F1(σxm)2+F2(σzm)2+F3σxmσzm+F4(σxzm)2+F5σxm +F6σzm≥1 (31.2)F1=1σu,tmσu,cm,F2=K2σu,tmσu,cm,F3=-F1F2,F4=1Sm,F5=σu,cm-σu,tmσu,tmσu,cm,F6=K'×F5 where σu,tm, σu,cm and Sm are the matrix tensile, compressive and shear strengths, respectively, measured using pure material specimens. The stress components σxm, σzm and σxzm in equation (31.1) are calculated using the Bridging Model.

sec.title: Plastic behavior of matrix
sec.p: A Von Mises stress of the matrix is modified to (32)σem=(σxm)2+(Kσzm)2-(σxm)(Kσzm)+3(σxzm)2 whereas the plastic component of the matrix instantaneous compliance matrix, specified through the Prandtl-Reuss theory,1 should be changed to (33.1)[Sijm]p=94MTm(σem)2[σ11'σ11' σ22'σ11' 2σ1 2'σ1 1' σ22'σ22' 2σ1 2'σ22' symmetry 4σ12'σ12'] (33.2)MTm=EmETmEm-ETm, (33.3)σ11'=(2σxm-Kσzm)/3,σ22'=(2Kσzm-σxm)/3,σ12'=σxzm

ETm is a secant modulus to a uniaxial stress–strain curve of the matrix up to failure, which whether under tension or compression depends on the following condition (34.1)σm1+σm2+σm3≥0,essential tension (34.2)σm1+σm2+σm3<0,essential compression where σm1, σm2 and σm3 are the three principal stresses of the matrix. The stress components σxm, σzm and σxzm in equations (32) and (33.3) are calculated using the Bridging Model.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: It can be seen that the expression of KII is the same as that given in Reference [7]. So in the following, we mainly discuss the influence of an interface layer on KI. In order for the equations obtained above to be applicable with the Bridging Model, the volume fraction of an interface layer, Vc, must be small enough. A variation of Vc versus Vf and thickness t of the interface layer is plotted in Figure 3, showing that when t ≤ 0.05a and Vf ≤ 0.65, the biggest value of Vc is 6.66%. For a given thickness, Vc is increased with an increase in Vf. Therefore, in the following, the thickness of an interface layer will be assumed to be t ≤ 0.05a.

sec.title: Strength prediction for UD composites
sec.p:
To verify the efficiency of a SCF obtained in this paper, three UD composites taken from Reference [4] are to be analyzed. According to Reference [4], all of the three composites are subjected to different combinations of bi-axial in-plane loads, and strength envelopes of them should be predicted. Processing conditions for the three laminae are given in Table 1. Bridging parameters, β Figure 3.
Vc (%) varied with fiber volume fraction and interface layer thickness.
Table 1.
Properties of three used UD laminae
Property E-glass/ LY556 T300/ BSL914C E-glass/ MY750
Fiber volume fraction Vf (%) 0.62 0.6 0.6
Curing temperature T0 (°C) 120 120 120
Working temperature T1 (°C) 25 25 25
α 0.35 0.35 0.35
β 0.45 0.45 0.45
and α, has been adjusted in such a way that the predicted transverse and in-plane shear moduli of the composite correlate reasonably with the provided counterparts. All of the constituent fiber and matrix properties for the composites have been provided in Reference [4] and are re-summarized in Table 2. The fiber strengths are determined through back retrieving by means of the Bridging Model. This is because a fiber strength is generally not measured directly upon very thin fiber specimens but obtained by retrieval from a composite strength using some micromechanics theory. All of the matrix strengths are taken from the provided data except for the shear strength of the LY556 matrix which was not provided. The latter strength is back calculated from the provided in-plane shear strength of the lamina made of the matrix. Furthermore, the plastic parameters of the three matrix materials are taken from Reference [2] and are listed in Table 3.

Unfortunately, no experimental data relevant to the interface layer of a composite were provided in Reference [4]. In fact, it is generally not an easy task to experimentally determine the characteristic parameters of an interface layer, such as thickness, elastic modulus and Poisson’s ratio, in a composite. Different test methods may lead to major differences. Reference [21] listed different experimental results for an interface layer thickness of the same composite system from different methods. For the glass-fiber/epoxy composite, the thickness of the interface layer was 30–240 nm with a differential scanning calorimetry method, but that was 1 μm when a secondary ion mass spectroscopy technique was used. Due to this reason, the thickness, elastic modulus and Poisson’s ratio of an interface layer are assigned within their appropriate ranges.

Let us agree to set the thickness of the interface layer be 0.05a for the composites to be considered. Corresponding to different moduli of the interface layer, i.e. Ec = 0.1Em, Ec = 0.5Em, Ec = 2Em and Ec = 100Em, the SCFs KI, KII and K in the matrix material of each of the three composite systems have been calculated. These results together with those without any interface layer (i.e., a perfect bonding between the fiber and the matrix) are listed in Table 4. During the calculation, a constant Poisson’s ratio of μc = 0.35 for the interface layer is assumed. Substituting the thus obtained SCF into equation (31.2), a matrix failure can be detected using Tsai-Wu criterion upon the originally provided matrix strength data. The predicted failure envelopes of the three UD composites under given bi-axial load combinations are graphed in Figures 4 through 6, respectively. It is noted that only the predicted curves based on Ec = 0.1Em and Ec = 2Em are Table 2.

plotted in the figures, since the biggest difference between KI and K0I is less than 2% when Ec = 0.5Em, Ec = 2Em and Ec = 100Em, where K0I is calculated from equation (26) with a perfect bonding assumption, i.e., with t = 0. In other words, the predicted curves on Ec = 0.5Em and Ec = 100Em are essentially the same as those on Ec = 2Em.

For the UD composite made of E-glass/LY556 system subjected to combined transverse and in-plane shear loads, the predicted failure envelope with a soft interface layer (Ec = 0.1Em) correlates with the available Table 4.
Stress concentration factors for different laminae (t = 0.05a, μc = 0.35)
E-glass/LY556 T300/BSL914C E-glass/MY750

experimental data better than the predictions with the other two interface conditions, i.e. a perfect bonding interface and a stiffer interface layer (Ec = 2Em). This can be seen from Figure 4. The predicted envelopes shown in Figure 5, however, seem to have insignificant differences when different interface conditions are assumed. The reason is that the envelopes in Figure 5 are due to combined shear and axial stresses applied on the composite, which result in insignificant transverse stress component in the matrix. Even though the different SCFs have been applied to such stress, the resulting value still has not reached a dominant level to cause the composite failure. Moreover, although the predicted curves in Figure 6 seem to differ from each other more than in Figure 5, it is not appropriate to say which curve is more close to the experimental data. Figure 4.
Comparison between predictions and experiments for E-glass/LY556 system.
Figure 5.
Comparison between predictions and experiments for T300/BSL914C system.

Additional comparisons with different interface layer conditions incorporated are plotted in Figures 7–10. As aforementioned, for the UD composite made of T300/BSL914C system subjected to combined longitudinal and in-plane shear loads, its ultimate strength is less influenced by an SCF used. Hence, the more comparisons are conducted only for the other two composites. Figures 7 and 8 present the results varied with different interface layer thicknesses while Ec = 0.1Em and μc = 0.35 are assumed for the interface layer properties Figure 6.
Comparison between predictions and experiments for E-glass/MY750 system.
Figure 7.
Comparison of predictions with different interface layer thickness for E-glass/LY556 system.
of both the E-Glass/LY556 and the E-Glass/MY750 systems. Figures 9 and 10 show the predicted envelopes based on different Poisson’s ratios for the interface layer in which Ec = 0.1Em and t = 0.05a are kept unchanged.

With a change in the interface layer thickness, distinct differences between the predicted failure envelopes can be found in Figures 7 and 8, respectively. When the modulus of the interface layer is smaller than that of matrix (e.g., Ec = 0.1Em), both the composites can sustain a higher strength with a thicker interface layer. It seems that the strength envelopes are expanded with an increase in the interface layer thickness. However, Figures 9 and 10 show a reversed tendency. With fixed thickness and modulus for an interface layer, when its Poisson’s ratio increases from 0.2 to 0.4, the Figure 8.
Comparison of predictions with different interface layer thickness for E-glass/MY750 system.
Figure 9.
Comparison of predictions with different Poisson’s ratio of interface layer for E-glass/LY556 system.
predicted strength envelopes become contracted. All of the predicted curves in Figures 7–10 correlate reasonably well with the corresponding experimental data.

From the comparison between the predicted and the measured ultimate strengths for the three composite examples, it is likely able to draw a conclusion that the introduction of an interface layer condition does not result in overall poorer correlation. If a much softer interface layer is assumed, which means that the elastic modulus of the interface layer is considerably smaller than that of the matrix, the predicted results can be better than those obtained with a perfect bonding condition. We have also obtained the results with t = 0.01a. It is noted that a thinner interface layer assumption of t = 0.01a does not give any visible difference between the predicted results with and without an interface layer, so no additional plots are shown in the paper. Figure 10.
Comparison of predictions with different Poisson’s ratio of interface layer for E-glass/MY750 system.
Figure 11.
KθI with different Ec when t = 0.01a.

sec.title: SCF vs interface layer property
sec.p: The influence of interface layer parameters on SCFs will be explored in the following. For this purpose, we consider a UD composite made of E-Glass/ MY750 system whose material properties are taken from Reference [4] and are summarized in Tables 1 and 2.

Variations of KθI with respect to different interface moduli are calculated based on a fixed Poisson’s ratio of μc = 0.35. The results are graphed in Figure 11 when the interface layer thickness is assumed to be t = 0.01a, in Figure 12 when t = 0.03a and in Figure 13 when t = 0.05a. The figures reveal that the influence of the Young’s modulus of an interface layer on stress concentration in the matrix is significant even though the Figure 12.
KθI with different Ec when t = 0.03a.
Figure 13.
KθI with different Ec when t = 0.05a.
thickness of the interface layer is small. From the Figures 11–13, we can see that in most cases the curves of KθI show a similar trend. Namely, from 0° to 90°, the value of KθI increases gradually and attains its maximum at θ = 90°, whereas from 90° to 180°, the reverse is true. However, such an influence by the modulus is combined with the thickness of the interface layer. As long as the elastic modulus Ec ≥ 0.05Em, the KθI assumes its maximum value at θ = 90° for all the thickness values considered. When the interface layer is very soft such as Ec = 0.01Em, the variation of KθI depends on the layer thickness: at t = 0.01a, the KθI Figure 14.
KI vs Ec when Ec ≤ 0.5 Em.
Figure 15.
KI vs Ec when Ec ≥ 0.5 Em.
still attains the maximum at θ = 90°; if at t ≥ 0.03a, the maximum KθI occurs θ = 0°. Furthermore, with the very small value of Ec, the thicker the interface layer, the higher value assumed by KθI at θ = 0°; in other words, KI becomes bigger as the interface layer gets thicker.

Variations of KI as a function of Ec/Em are plotted in Figures 14 and 15. The figures show that given the interface layer modulus if much smaller than that of the matrix, KI varies a lot when the thickness of the layer becomes larger. However, when the interface layer modulus is moderate such as equal or greater than half of the matrix modulus, essentially no or only little change occurs to KI no matter how much a thickness can be assumed by the interface layer. More accurate comparison for KI varied with different combinations of the interface layer modulus and Table 5.
KI varied with elastic modulus and thickness of an interface layer (μc = 0.35)
t = 0 (ideal) t = 0.002a t = 0.01a t = 0.02a t = 0.03a t = 0.05a
Ec = 0.1 Em 1.4727 1.4732 1.4629 1.4361 1.4034 1.3347
Ec = 0.2 Em 1.4727 1.4733 1.4722 1.4654 1.4551 1.4291
Ec = 0.5 Em 1.4727 1.4731 1.4743 1.4748 1.4745 1.4720
Ec = 2 Em 1.4727 1.4729 1.4739 1.4751 1.4762 1.4782
Ec = 10 Em 1.4727 1.4728 1.4734 1.4741 1.4746 1.4752
Ec = 100 Em 1.4727 1.4724 1.4715 1.4707 1.4701 1.4690
Figure 16.
KθI with different μc when t = 0.05a, Ec = 0.5 Em.
thickness is given in Table 5. It is seen from the table that the biggest difference between the KI and the KθI obtained on a perfect bonding interface condition is 9.37%.

Let us then consider the influence of Poisson’s ratio μc of an interface layer on a stress concentration in the matrix. Setting the thickness of the interface layer as t = 0.05a, variations of KθI versus different values of μc (μc = 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) are plotted in Figures 16 and 17, respectively. In Figure 16, a softer interface layer than the matrix modulus of Ec = 0.5Em whereas in Figure 17 a stiffer one of Ec = 2Em is used. Distinct differences can be found in Figure 16 only when KθI attains its maximum value, whereas in Figure 17 very little difference can be recognized. This means that the influence of μc on the KI may be taken into account when the thickness of the interface layer becomes relatively large and when the elastic modulus of the interface layer is smaller than that of the matrix. We have also calculated the variations of KθI when the interface layer thickness takes a smaller value, i.e. when t = 0.01a. As the layer thickness becomes smaller, less difference in KθI occurs and hence no additional plot is shown in this paper. A summary of KI in accordance with different Poisson’s ratios μc is listed in Table 6. A maximal variation of less than 4% is seen. Thus, the Poisson’s ratio effect of an interface layer on KI is insignificant in general.

Finally, the influence of an interface layer thickness t on KI is investigated. The calculated results are graphed in Figure 18. During the calculation, a constant Poisson’s ratio of μc = 0.35 is used. From Figure 18, we can see that when the elastic modulus of the interface layer is considerably smaller than that of the matrix, KI lowers down with an increase in the Figure 17.
KθI with different μc when t = 0.05a, Ec = 2 Em.
Table 6.
KI varied with Poisson’s ratio of an interface layer (when t = 0, KI = 1.4727)
Poisson ratio KI
t = 0.01a t = 0.05a
Ec = 0.5 Em Ec = 2 Em Ec = 0.5 Em Ec = 2 Em
μc = 0.2 1.4669 1.4719 1.4395 1.4688
μc = 0.3 1.4712 1.4731 1.4584 1.4744
μc = 0.4 1.4781 1.4749 1.4896 1.4830
Figure 18.
KI vs interface layer thickness.
thickness. However, when the elastic modulus of the interface layer is not smaller than one half of that of the matrix, i.e. Ec ≥ 0.5Em, no obvious effect of a varied thickness t on KI can be recognized.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The influence of a thin interface layer on stress concentration in the matrix of a composite is studied in this paper. Explicit expression for the SCF with an interface layer is obtained. The matrix in-situ strengths are defined as its monolithic strengths divided by the SCF. It has been found that when the interface layer thickness is very small such as t ≤ 0.01a where a is the radius of the fiber, the introduction of the interface layer has essentially no effect on the matrix in-situ strengths compared with a perfect bonding assumption for the fiber and the matrix interface. However, when the interface layer thickness becomes larger such as t = 0.05a, the matrix in-situ strengths vary with the interface layer modulus noticeably. A much softer interface layer than the matrix assumption such as Ec = 0.1Em can result in improved prediction for the composite strengths. In any case, however, the introduction of an interface layer between the fiber and the matrix does not bring overall poorer correlation between the predicted and the measured strengths of the composite.

sec.p: Partial financial support from the Natural Science Foundation of China with a grant number of 11272238 and from the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities with a grant number of 1330-219-104 is acknowledged.

app.title: Appendix
app.p: From an Airy stress function U, three stress components in a polar coordinate system are given by (A1)σr=∂Ur∂r+1r2∂2U∂θ2σθ=∂2U∂r2σrθ=-∂2∂r(1r∂U∂θ)
